title: Reverse a Linked List
description: Implement a function to reverse a singly linked list in-place. The function should take the head of the list and return the new head after reversal.
hints: Use three pointers: previous, current, and next
Iterate through the list and reverse the next pointer of each node
Don't forget to handle the edge case of an empty list

title: Find Middle of Linked List
description: Find and return the middle node of a linked list. If there are two middle nodes (even length), return the second one.
starterCode:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value
        self.next = None

def find_middle(head):
    # Your code here
    pass

# Test
head = Node(1)
head.next = Node(2)
head.next.next = Node(3)
print(find_middle(head).value)
solution:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value
        self.next = None

def find_middle(head):
    slow = fast = head
    while fast and fast.next:
        slow = slow.next
        fast = fast.next.next
    return slow

head = Node(1)
head.next = Node(2)
head.next.next = Node(3)
print(find_middle(head).value)
hints: Use two pointers: slow and fast
Fast moves 2 steps while slow moves 1

title: Detect Cycle in Linked List
description: Determine if a linked list has a cycle. Return True if there is a cycle, False otherwise.
hints: Use Floyd's cycle detection (tortoise and hare)
If fast catches up to slow, there's a cycle

title: Array Rotation
description: Rotate an array to the right by k positions. For example, [1,2,3,4,5] rotated by 2 becomes [4,5,1,2,3].
starterCode:
def rotate_array(arr, k):
    # Modify arr in-place
    pass

arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
rotate_array(arr, 2)
print(arr)
solution:
def rotate_array(arr, k):
    n = len(arr)
    k = k % n  # Handle k > n
    
    def reverse(start, end):
        while start < end:
            arr[start], arr[end] = arr[end], arr[start]
            start += 1
            end -= 1
    
    reverse(0, n - 1)
    reverse(0, k - 1)
    reverse(k, n - 1)

arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
rotate_array(arr, 2)
print(arr)
hints: Use the reversal algorithm: reverse all, then reverse first k, then reverse rest
Handle k > array length with modulo

title: Doubly Linked List

title: LRU Cache Implementation
description: Implement an LRU (Least Recently Used) cache using a hash map and doubly linked list. Support get() and put() in O(1) time.
starterCode:
class LRUCache:
    def __init__(self, capacity):
        self.capacity = capacity
        # Your code here
    
    def get(self, key):
        # Return -1 if not found
        pass
    
    def put(self, key, value):
        # Evict LRU if at capacity
        pass

cache = LRUCache(2)
cache.put(1, 1)
cache.put(2, 2)
print(cache.get(1))
cache.put(3, 3)  # evicts key 2
print(cache.get(2))
solution:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, key, value):
        self.key = key
        self.value = value
        self.prev = None
        self.next = None

class LRUCache:
    def __init__(self, capacity):
        self.capacity = capacity
        self.cache = {}
        self.head = Node(0, 0)
        self.tail = Node(0, 0)
        self.head.next = self.tail
        self.tail.prev = self.head
    
    def _remove(self, node):
        node.prev.next = node.next
        node.next.prev = node.prev
    
    def _add_to_front(self, node):
        node.next = self.head.next
        node.prev = self.head
        self.head.next.prev = node
        self.head.next = node
    
    def get(self, key):
        if key in self.cache:
            node = self.cache[key]
            self._remove(node)
            self._add_to_front(node)
            return node.value
        return -1
    
    def put(self, key, value):
        if key in self.cache:
            self._remove(self.cache[key])
        node = Node(key, value)
        self._add_to_front(node)
        self.cache[key] = node
        if len(self.cache) > self.capacity:
            lru = self.tail.prev
            self._remove(lru)
            del self.cache[lru.key]

cache = LRUCache(2)
cache.put(1, 1)
cache.put(2, 2)
print(cache.get(1))
cache.put(3, 3)
print(cache.get(2))
hints: Use dummy head/tail nodes to avoid edge cases
HashMap stores key -> Node for O(1) lookup
Move accessed nodes to front

move_zeroes(nums)

title: Remove Nth Node from End
description: Given a linked list, remove the nth node from the end of the list and return the head. Use a single pass if possible.
solution:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value
        self.next = None

def remove_nth_from_end(head, n):
    dummy = Node(0)
    dummy.next = head
    fast = slow = dummy
    
    # Move fast n+1 steps ahead
    for _ in range(n + 1):
        fast = fast.next
    
    # Move both until fast reaches end
    while fast:
        fast = fast.next
        slow = slow.next
    
    # Remove the nth node
    slow.next = slow.next.next
    return dummy.next
hints: Use two pointers with n nodes gap between them
Use a dummy node to handle edge case of removing head

title: Intersection of Two Linked Lists
description: Given the heads of two singly linked-lists, return the node at which they intersect. If no intersection, return None.
hints: If we traverse A+B and B+A, both paths have same length
They will meet at intersection or both reach None

title: Product of Array Except Self
description: Given an integer array nums, return an array where output[i] equals the product of all elements except nums[i]. Solve without using division and in O(n) time.
starterCode:
def product_except_self(nums):
    # Return array of products
    pass

print(product_except_self([1, 2, 3, 4]))
solution:
def product_except_self(nums):
    n = len(nums)
    result = [1] * n
    
    # Left pass: result[i] = product of all elements left of i
    left_product = 1
    for i in range(n):
        result[i] = left_product
        left_product *= nums[i]
    
    # Right pass: multiply by product of all elements right of i
    right_product = 1
    for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
        result[i] *= right_product
        right_product *= nums[i]
    
    return result

print(product_except_self([1, 2, 3, 4]))
hints: Use prefix and suffix products
First pass: compute prefix products
Second pass: multiply by suffix products

title: Palindrome Linked List
description: Determine if a singly linked list is a palindrome. Can you do it in O(n) time and O(1) space?
solution:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value
        self.next = None

def is_palindrome(head):
    if not head or not head.next:
        return True
    
    # Find middle
    slow = fast = head
    while fast.next and fast.next.next:
        slow = slow.next
        fast = fast.next.next
    
    # Reverse second half
    prev = None
    curr = slow.next
    while curr:
        next_node = curr.next
        curr.next = prev
        prev = curr
        curr = next_node
    
    # Compare halves
    first, second = head, prev
    while second:
        if first.value != second.value:
            return False
        first = first.next
        second = second.next
    
    return True
hints: Find the middle using slow/fast pointers
Reverse the second half
Compare first half with reversed second half

title: Find the Duplicate Number
description: Given an array of n+1 integers where each integer is in [1, n], find the duplicate. There is exactly one duplicate which may appear more than once. Solve without modifying the array and using only O(1) extra space.
starterCode:
def find_duplicate(nums):
    # Your code here
    pass

print(find_duplicate([1, 3, 4, 2, 2]))
solution:
def find_duplicate(nums):
    # Floyd's cycle detection (treat array as linked list)
    slow = fast = nums[0]
    
    # Find intersection point
    while True:
        slow = nums[slow]
        fast = nums[nums[fast]]
        if slow == fast:
            break
    
    # Find cycle start
    slow = nums[0]
    while slow != fast:
        slow = nums[slow]
        fast = nums[fast]
    
    return slow

print(find_duplicate([1, 3, 4, 2, 2]))
hints: Treat array values as "next pointers" - nums[i] points to index nums[i]
A duplicate means two indices point to same location = cycle
Use Floyd's cycle detection to find the duplicate

title: Reorder List
description: Given a singly linked list L0→L1→...→Ln-1→Ln, reorder it to L0→Ln→L1→Ln-1→L2→Ln-2→... Do this in-place without modifying node values.
solution:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value
        self.next = None

def reorder_list(head):
    if not head or not head.next:
        return
    
    # Find middle
    slow = fast = head
    while fast.next and fast.next.next:
        slow = slow.next
        fast = fast.next.next
    
    # Reverse second half
    prev = None
    curr = slow.next
    slow.next = None
    while curr:
        next_node = curr.next
        curr.next = prev
        prev = curr
        curr = next_node
    
    # Merge two halves
    first, second = head, prev
    while second:
        tmp1, tmp2 = first.next, second.next
        first.next = second
        second.next = tmp1
        first = tmp1
        second = tmp2
hints: Find the middle of the list
Reverse the second half
Merge the two halves by alternating nodes

title: Dynamic Array Implementation
description: Implement a dynamic array (like Python list or Java ArrayList) that automatically resizes. Support append, pop, get, set, and size operations.
hints: Double capacity when array is full
Halve capacity when 1/4 full (to avoid thrashing)
Amortized O(1) for append operations
